text:
FANTASTIC! This was a great baked chicken. I changed some things to make it even more flavorful for us. For the breadcrumb mixture I substituted "pepperidge farm herb stuffing" instead of plain bread crumbs and also added 1 tsp oregano along with the basil. I used 4 large chicken breasts and used 4 tbsp olive oil and 2 cloves garlic. I also sprinkled a little salt and pepper on the chicken breasts before dipping them into the oil/garlic mixture. Oh to make this easier, use 2 pie pans for the dipping. It's so much easier than a bowl.. unless the chicken breasts are smaller or tenders. I did not think there was too much breadcrumb mixture as other reviewers said. I did have a little bit of each leftover (oil and breadcrumb), so I first drizzled what was left of the oil on the prepared chicken breasts in the pan, and then sprinkled what was left of the breadcrmb mixture over this. Then I sprinkled all of this with some garlic powder. It took about 40 minutes for the chicken to be done. It was SO MOIST and SO FLAVORFUL. Better and SO MUCH EASIER than my usual parmensan chicken recipe. WILL MAKE AGAIN AND AGAIN. Thanks!

text:
With  my modifications, it came out perfect! Used 6 chicken breasts. Was out of italian breadcrumbs so used chicken flavored stove top stuffing crushed well. Used 4 tbsps of olive oil and 2 tsps minced garlic. Put chicken breasts in a ziplock bag, added garlic, oil mixture, added 2 tsps adobo, 1 tsp each of salt & pepper, mixed well. Dipped the chicken pieces in the crumb/parmesan cheese mixture and baked for 40 minutes at 350 degrees. I've made similar recipes and they've lacked in flavor - this is the first time the flavor was perfect (in my opinion!) so I made sure to write it down this time!! This is one of those great recipes that is perfect for altering to your preference. Thanks for sharing!

text:
This is a great recipe.  Here's what I did with it.  I added melted butter to the olive oil (about equal amounts), used Japanese style panko crumbs and FRESH parmesan.  I pounded the breasts to ensure even and quick cooking and after they were baked (I cooked them at 375 degrees for 30 minutes)I put a little sun dried tomato pesto on top of each one and covered that with slices of mozza cheese.  I then put the pan under a hot broiler for a minute.  The only part that took any time was pounding the breasts.  I whipped this up for unexpected dinner guests and served it on a bed of rice pilaf on a large platter.  It tasted great and it looked impressive.  Everyone loved it and there were no leftovers.  Do try the panko crumbs if you can find them as they make a light crispy coating and the texture is more appealing than regular bread crumbs.

text:
Really great, pretty healthy, chicken dish. Cooked exactly 30 minutes and they were perfect. I used panko bread crumbs because I think they offer a better crunch. Also, I cooked the chicken on a cooling rack and flipped them half way through so that they wouldn't get soggy on the bottom. A trick I learned watching America's Test Kitchen.

text:
Let me start by saying that I hate breaded chicken.  I decided to give this a try because I was pressed for time.  We only eat chicken/ fish/veggies/grains and sometimes it gets boring.  I was completely amazed that this was so good!  I used a little more garlic, seasoned bread crumbs, and a dash of italian seasoning and season salt.  I also used a softer parmesan cheese that made all the difference.  Chicken was juicy and full of flavor.  By the way, organic chicken will always taste better!  Those in doubt..it is a keeper!

text:
The Chicken was beautiful, but the recipe doesnt call for the chicken to be seasoned, I suggest that you do if only with mrs dash or salt even. But otherwise it was superb! It went well with mashes patatoes (my creativity) and DONT cover the pan with foil when baking because it will come out soggy. So leave it as is and sprinkle enough of the excess breadcrumbs over the top of the chicken. And the recipe calls for way too much breadcrumbs and after you dip the chicken in the breadcrumbs you MUST throw them away (contamination etc..) and that is a massive waste, USE YOUR DISCRETION. OTHERWISE THE CHICKEN WAS SUPERB!
 Rhyan, Bahamas

text:
Our family really enjoyed this chicken. This meal was extremely flavorful, and juicy, perhaps adjusting the spices to our liking did it. I would recommend this to anyone who would like to try something a bit different for dinner. I did make the following changes: I allowed the minced garlic to sit in the oil for about 10 mins. and added Italian seasoning and garlic powder to the bread crumbs. I also used Italian bread crumbs and pounded out the chicken into thin cutlets, turned it under the broiler for five minutes and topped with shredded mozzarella while under the broiler.

text:
I've made this dozens of times.  Put a little oil in your baking pan.  Squeeze the fresh garlic into that.  Sit in just a barely warm oven for a few minutes to let the garlic rest and flavors mix.  Then dip and roll your chicken in that and then roll in the bread crumb/parmesan cheese mixture.  Put back in the same baking dish and bake!  That's all I do.  Plain bread crumbs with parmesan cheese.  It really doesn't need any other flavors mixed together.  It's a wonderful easy moist dish!

text:
I gave this four stars because it is easy, inexpensive, and great for leftovers.  The taste is good, too.  To me, this recipe is a "base" recipe.  That means it is just the starting point.  The recipe has a basic flavor so you can personalize it in many ways.  Serve on spaghetti with sauce, serve on wild rice with mushroom cream sauce, serve on a bun with mayo for a sandwich, etc.  I followed other reviewer advice and cooked on a rack, turning 1/2 thru cooking time.  Turned out perfect.  And, I broiled it for 5 minutes with mozzarella cheese at the end.  I do not pay attention to overall scores anymore, so those who are all worked up about how others review a recipe need to relax.  Instead, read the reviews and you can get so many interesting hints on how to tweak a recipe.  To me, sharing and learning from others is important, as I am not a "wanna be" professional chef.  Thank you.

text:
RATING AS PER ORIGINAL RECIPE= AVERAGE.  I made this recipe only looking at the rating and number of reviews; I should have known better.  The “most helpful” reviews all modified it in one way or another.  In the end the recipe does need to be modified because it is bland and the “crust” doesn’t come out crusty at all.  All the reviewers made modification to remedy these aspects: change to panko, Italian breadcrumbs, drizzling oil to moisten the bread crumb mixture, double the oil and garlic mixture, or add mozzarella. 
It wasn’t bad, just really ordinary.  I could make several modifications and make this more appealing as per the reviews.  That being said, I would rather keep a similar but better recipe in my recipe box, for which I would not have to keep notes as to the substantial modification that it needs.

I have used this exact receipe for years and love it.  For a change, after the chicken has baked, put a slice of mozzarella or provolone cheese on top of each breast and pour your favorit sauce over it.  Put it back in the oven until the sauce bubbles and the cheese melts.

text:
I make a similar chicken recipe.  Instead of dipping the chicken in oil, I use an egg wash (a beaten egg with a T. of water).  I use panko bread crumbs and romano, instead of regular bread crumbs and parmesan.  Then I brown each side of the chicken before baking.  Also, try to cut large breasts in half lengthwise.  It will get done much faster.  I serve the chicken with pasta and a half and half mix of marinara and alfredo.  This is a favorite.

text:
These are great baked chicken breasts. I didn't use all of the crumb mixture (actually about half) and needed more of the olive oil and garlic . I also added a bit more garlic because I love the stuff! I brined my chicken breasts in a saltwater solution for a while before follwing the recipe so they would retain moisture, drying them with a towel before putting them in the olive oil. They were very moist. I served with a marinara sauce and some melted Italian cheeses. Delicious!

Superb dish and easy to do! I made it even easier by coating the chicken in pesto sauce instead of using dried basil and oil. This allowed me to cut down on the Parmesan as the sauce has cheese in it of course. I also used garlic paste from a jar!
As pesto can be salty, be careful when adding seasoning!

text:
Delicious! I've been making something similar for years and it's definitely a favorite in this house. Instead of olive oil I use an egg wash and did the chicken twice to get a nice coating of breading. I added some garlic, oregano, basil and parsley to the bread crumb mixture for a nice herbed flavor. I spray a glass baking dish with Olive Oil PAM and turn the chicken once during cooking. Very simple and very good!

I was looking for something quick, easy and tasteful to do with BLSL chicken breast.  This fit the bill.  The only thing that I did differently was to use Panko Bread Crumbs with Italian Seasoning.  The crumb mixture with the parmesan would also be good on fish or pork chops.  Will keep to use again. UPDATE:  I cooked this again last night using the Panko Bread crumbs and we loved it.  This is an easy, easy way to cook BLSL chicken, that is tasty.

text:
All my kids loved this recipe and gave it 5 stars.  I took the advice from the other reviews and marinated the chicken in Italian dressing before I dipped the chicken pieces in 2./3 cup grated parmesan cheese, 1 TBSP Italian seasonings, 1/2 tsp garlic salt and 1 cup Panko bread crumbs.  I had to bake the chicken 50 minutes since my chicken was on the thick side.  The chicken came out crunchy on the outside and tender on the inside.  Enjoy!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1242826.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making a version of this recipe for about 30 yrs. now- here is what I do. I melt about 1/4- 1/3 cup of butter with several (3-4) cloves of garlic that I put through my garlic press. I make fresh breadcrumbs in my food processor( use whatever type bread is on hand). I mix the fresh crumbs with freshly grated Parmesan Reggiano, salt, pepper,some sesame seeds,& some finely chopped fresh basil. I coat the chicken in the butter then pack on the coating, lay them on a baking sheet & depending on the thickness, bake 30-40 min. @ 375. This may not be the healthiest method but it sure is the tastiest & I can be sure of several requests for the recipe. It's also wonderful cold. My family always liked it served with a salad & scalloped potatoes.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved this recipe just as it is.. but had to write to give a variation of this using a whole chicken with skin still on: Up the garlic to 3 bulbs, eliminate the breadcrumbs entirely, and substitute the basil for dill.  Add 1/2 an onion and 1/2 a lemon with zest. I realize that this is a quite a different meal, but it was totally inspired by this one and I love crispy chicken skin (my bad)! Smear the oil/garlic/lemon+zest all over and in the chicken. Sprinkle S&P, dill, parmesan inside and out of the chicken.  Cut onion in 4 and put one piece in the chicken and 3 out.  Put a couple of slices of lemon in an open pan. (cast iron fry pan is great.) Bake 350 until leg turns loosely.. baste and cook 10 more minutes to crisp. yum! Thanks for the inspiration!

text:
The whole family loved this recipe. Even my 3 extremely picky kids, including my oldest who rarely eats any dinner I make so that says a lot. My husband said "Wow this is really good chicken," and the best part about it was how quick and easy it is to make. I did use half butter and half olive oil in the oil dipping mixture and used about 6-8  minced garlic cloves which I simmered in the butter/olive oil before dipping the chicken into it and I used Panko instead of bread crumbs and then turned up the heat to 425 durung the last half of cooking thinking that might give it a ccrispier crust. This turned out great and will now be a regular meal for us. My only issue was I didnlt spray the pam with cooking spray and it stuck to the pan so I would recommend spraying the pan before cooking. Thanks so much for posting. Can't wait to make this again.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Very surprised with all the five star reviews.  I just finished preparing and eating this dish and found the recipe to be fundamentally flawed in a number of ways.  

I started out with 4 pieces of chicken and even with two less pieces than the recipe called for, the amount of EVOO and garlic was not enough.  I added one extra clove of fresh garlic and another splash or two of EVOO to sufficiently coat 4 pieces of chicken.  

The crust cooked up nice and crunchy and it looks great when done.  I used panko breadcrumbs which probably helped some, but upon taking my first bite, I found the flavor to be lacking.  It was actually quite dull and uninspiring.  If you are looking for a dish with some excitement, this certainly isn't it.   

I may experiment with it a little bit next time by adding some additional seasoning and perhaps some Italian dressing to kick it up a notch, but as written, this dish is a definite pass for me.

text:
As written this is a 4 star recipe, with small modifications it is an easy 5 star.  First off, THANK YOU for submitting this it was awesome.  I took others notes and used italian seasoned bread crumbs.  Also, I cooked the chicken on a cooling rack so they would not get soggy.  I topped the cooked chicken with motz and broiled, nice play on chichen parm.  Great meal.

text:
Great recipe!  I used chicken legs instead of breast, and I love garlic so I added a whole lot more.  I didn't add the Parmesean because I had run out, but the recipe was still great.  To the bread crumbs I mixed in some finely chopped Oregano.  In addition, I wrapped 2 slices of bacon around each leg.  Then I drizzled the remaining olive oil mixture over the chicken, and sprinkled the remaining bread crumbs too.  I've already made this recipe twice and it was a hit both times.

Display Name:
Tjernagels

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I absolutely love this recipe! Mine turned out very juicy and full of flavor. My boyfriend said it was the best chicken he had ever tasted and that it is restaurant quality. I read about 50 plus reviews before I tried it and then I proceeded with what I thought would be best. There's just one thing I want to clarify... I read a lot of reviews that said they used chicken breasts. The recipe calls for chicken breast halves which I'm sure makes a huge difference with flavor and time. I just cut my chicken breast lengthwise down the middle to get halves. I also pounded the thick part a little to bring it down to about an inch and a half of thickness. I used a cup of Japanese Style Plain Planko breadcrumbs, a cup of parmesan cheese, and about 6-7 large garlic cloves rather than the small amount the recipe called for. I also added a tsp of salt, tsp cayenne pepper, and a tsp oregano to the breadcrumb/parmesan mix. The timing was perfect.

userID:
14482136
Display Name:
Denise Morrison

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1566483.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best chicken parm recipe I've ever used! And so simple. I basically followed the recipe, only I did half butter half olive oil. I also used Panky bread crumbs and seasoned it with an Italian herb, salt and pepper. I used 3 large chicken beasts and pounded out the chicken and baked for 30 minutes at 350 then 10 more minutes at 375 (the bread crumbs weren't browning and clear juice wasn't coming out, so I upped the heat for 10 extra minutes). Then once it turned golden and it was sizzling with clear juices I added provolone cheese on top and broiled it for a couple minites. Served with spagetti and marinara sauce and a side salad. It was incredibly juicy and very very flavorful! I've also used an egg mixture to bread my chicken but I'm sold on the olive oil/butter and garlic now!!

text:
This chicken turned out very moist and yummy.  However, the recipe calls for more bread crumbs than you need and then directs you to pour the rest over the top before baking.  Nobody wanted to eat all those extra bread crumbs so we ended up raking most of them off.  I would probably make this again with less bread crumbs and without dumping the left over crumbs on top.

text:
I'm always looking for new and innovative ways to make boneless/skinless breasts and this was rather tasty. It definitely needed more seasoning on the chicken itself, not necessarily in the breadcrumbs. Instead of mincing garlic, I used my mortar and pestle to make a paste with the garlic & olive oil then dipped in Panko breadcrumbs for an extra crunch. The result was a nice, garlicky, crunchy dish. I will definitely try this one again.

text:
Oh wow!!! I am so impressed. I usually don't make baked chicken dishes, so this is my first one that I am so impressed with. Like most of us, I did alter a bit. I was making for just myself on a night my hubby and son were gone, so I only used enough ingredients and chicken for myself. First, I seasoned chicken with garlic salt then added lemon pepper seasoning to the bread crumb mixture. I threw more garlic in because I love love love the stuff. Cooked in baking dish for thirty, but for some reason when I went to take it out, it wasn't nearly done, so I cooked for ten more minutes and served it with garlic asparagus and a baked potato. Went great with a glass of chardonnay! I will definitely be making this again for my husband and son!

elp1

favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As an Italian who hasn't made chicken parmesan for years because fried chicken isn't good for you, I was pleasantly surprised with this basic recipe. It did not have enough garlic for my taste (I used about 15 cloves - one half of a giant head of garlic - instead of one clove). I also grew up using Romano cheese which is stronger and has more bite than Parmesan which is more popular among most Americans. Needless to say, I substituted Romano instead of Parmesan cheese. I had Progresso bread crumbs on hand which I used for the bread crumbs. Even though the bread crumbs had basilico in it already, you can never have too much basilico in my opinion, so I added additional basilico like the recipe called for.  When it was just about done I took it out of the oven, put pasta sauce and mozzarella cheese on it, and let it finish cooking until the cheese melted. It was a real hit with my seven year old who called it "chicken pizza".
Review:

text:
This was sooooo good : )  I ended up adding 1tsp of garlic powder, 1tsp onion powder and 1 tsp of Italian seasoning to the bread crumb mixture.  I used the Kraft grated parmesan cheese -  I find it sticks better to the chicken  than when I grate my own cheese (Maybe because that cheese is almost the same consistency as the bread crumbs?).  I also flipped the chicken breasts over after fifteen minutes of cooking to get even browning. I also put the chicken on a plate then sprinkled the crumbs on top of the chicken, that way I could still save any left over crumbs and use them again in the next few days.

text:
I made this recipe for my bf and I and we both loved it! This is definitely a keeper.. I just changed a couple things. I doubled the garlic and instead of using shredded parmesan I used grated parmesan cheese along with Italian bread crumbs. It tasted like something you'd order from a restaurant, it was that good! One side note..make sure you dont add too much if any salt to the mixture since the cheese and bread cumbs will make up for the salt. This would be great if used for chicken parmesan or just a side of broccoli and cheese over rice like we had. I added a bit of butter to the caserole dish and covered the chicken with foil and baked on 350 for 40mins.

text:
This recipe turned out tasty, moist, easy to prepare, and cooked fast. I used 4 large breasts, and I did not cut them. I found that I needed twice as much olive oil (about 4 tbs) to get them very moist before breading. I also used 3 cloves of minced garlic instead of 1. I found that after breading, putting the extra bread crumbs on top was not necessary. I also baked them for 45 minutes as the breasts were quite thick. This is an easy tasty no-brainer dinner.

WHAT I CHANGED (I'd give it 4 stars with my changes): 
Used Kellogs corn flakes crumbs instead of the bread crumbs so it'd be more crisp. Panko would have done well also. I added more garlic to the crumbs in addition to what was in the oil. After I put it in the pan, I topped with salt and oregano.

I also thought the chicken was too soft cooking it at 350 so about 10 minutes before I took it out I increased the temp to 425 to crust the outside.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/884201.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great easy meal! I took 9 frozen chicken breasts (4 hungry guys and me, so 2 each and 1 for me) and defrosted in the microwave for about 15 minutes with a few glugs of Olive Oil, salt, pepper and minced Garlic (I cheated and added it from the jar) and some butter to make it stick. (You can leave the kitchen, or in my case, the house for 30 minutes and work out during this time!)

Breasts all coated well and thawed, dip into mixture as stated but also added 1 cup of crushed Corn Flakes to give it more crunch and a dash of Cayenne Pepper and Garlic Salt. Chopped fresh Basil, because I have it in my garden and love it! Okay for you people that HATE when someone changes the recipe; there wouldn't be any comments if no one changed it to their liking! :) Topped with some Mozzarella cheese the last 10 minutes and turned up to 375. DON'T OVERCOOK! It was moist and delicious!  

Served with Seasoned Broccoli and Garlic Parmesan Mashed Potatoes.

text:
I rated this recipe 5 stars for many reasons -- 1 - my entire family loved it, which is difficult to achieve in my house; 2 - it was a piece of cake to prepare; 3 - the ingredients are readily available most of the time and 4 - it is good enough to serve company. I especially liked using olive oil instead of eggs for the first step in breading the chicken. Much easier, less messy and very tasty. I did add 2 extra cloves of garlic because my family loves garlic, but that is the only change I made. Thank you!!UPDATE: -- I accidentally added 1 tsp of oregano instead of basil, then added the basil anyway. It was wonderful, and that's how I make it now. I taught my non-cooking son how to make it, and he made it for his friends, who couldn't get enough of it. Excellent recipe.

text:
A great weeknight meal!  I use chicken tenders to cut the cooking time in half.  Before I leave for work in the morning, I put them in a Ziploc bag with the oil and garlic (put through a garlic press), adding salt and pepper to taste.  We like more garlicky flavor.  I use Italian breadcrumbs and omit the basil. While it cooks I make a green salad and some angel hair pasta (which also cooks quickly).  I serve the pasta with a little butter and parmesan, and it's a dinner everyone likes in about 30 minutes!

I needed a very quick and very easy recipe that took little or no effort, as I'm 8 months pregnant. This was so easy! And my husband and I really liked it. I took another reviewer's advice and covered the pan with foil; it crisped up the chicken a bit.
My suggestions: 1. don't top chicken with remaining bread crumbs, as it doesn't really do anything for the final product; 2. use a pastry brush to brush oil on instead of dipping chicken into oil.
Thanks for the recipe! It's a keeper!

Fantastic! I served it with mashed potatoes and steamed green beans. text:
Like many other reviewers on this site, I decided to tweak the recipe a bit and let you know how great this variation is.  My wife doesn't like chicken breasts so I substituted pork shoulder steaks.  Bread crumbs are out because we're gluten free so I went with cornmeal.  Since oil can be fattening, I used egg whites instead.  Not a big fan of basil so I selected saffron instead.  Anyway, I followed the rest of the recipe to the letter (wait, no, I baked the shoulder steaks at 375 for 40 minutes, sorry).  I plated this delicious dish and added a combination of ranch dressing and Durkee's hot sauce over the top to add flavor. Delicious!  My wife can't stop raving about these baked chicken breasts with garlic parmesan!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Instead of Olive Oil I use one or two beaten eggs with a dash of Dejonge mustard and garlic in a shallow bowl. In a Baggie I add Panko instead of breadcrumbs and sometimes mix itup with cornflake crumbs too, fresh grated Parmesan, a dash of Lawrys salt and pepper., some parsley for color.  ( helpful to pound the breasts for more tenderness prior to prep. ) spray .lightly with olive oil . 
Bake at 350 on a rack in a 9x13 pan. For 30 minutes.   This will crisp both sides of the chicken.
Been making this recipe for 40 years plus. Was my Moms recipe. We call it Chicken Parm 101!

text:
Made this garlic parmesan chicken tonight for my daughter, her boyfriend, my son and nephew, all in their 20's and they loved it.!  I tweaked it a bit by adding oregano, sun-dried tomato pesto and used Shake and Bake parmesan bread crumbs.  Served it over spaghetti, with salad and fingerling potatoes.  I must say it was absolutely delicious and everyone loved it.  I will definitely come back to this website for more recipes.

text:
This chicken was delicious!  The only thing I would recommend is doubling the olive oil and add a 2nd garlic clove.  Everything else was followed exactly how the recipe was listed.  Some people said it had no flavor, this is definitely not the case.  It was extremely flavorful and the bread crumbs did create a crispy coating.  I too get extremely annoyed when people change the recipe and then rate the original recipe.  Rate the listed recipe, we don't want to hear what you did to change it to suit your tastes!  Thank you Karen for this wonderful recipe which I will definitely be making again.

text:
This is my second go at this, first one was great and the second one would be no different. I changed the recipe for 8 servings.
That is correct in some of the reviews about not enough oil to coat six servings much less my eight servings. Those who whine about not enough oil sounds like they've never been in the kitchen before?
I pour in about a 1/2 cup of Olive oil and mince the garlic to look like it covers most of the bottom. Come on guys, Really!

text:
This recipe is so yummy! I took the advice of another user & put the oil and garlic into a zip lock bag and coated 1 chicken breast at a time. I also roasted the garlic prior to adding it to the oil. The chicken comes out so flavorful & tender! I think the next time I make this, I'll put the chicken on a rack inside the pan, to raise it up & allow the bottom to become crisp, too. I paired the chicken with roasted veggies & my man loved it! Another allrecipes success!

I made the recipe AS IS and it was easy and delicious. The chicken was flavorful and juicy. I'm completely confused by the folks saying it was bland. text:
Amazing. Instead of basil I used fresh ground thyme also added some granulated onion and garlic.  Lastly some French onions crunched up in the crumbs.  
Seen on another site that Italian dressing was used instead of oil of course all the ingredients weren't there  but that tastes better than oil.  Then even use Italian bread crumbs.  Yum ! Only ten minutes most prep and so worth it!  This is the first time I've successfully made bread crumb chicken without it all falling off. A lot to do with the greasing of the pan I'm guessing. So worth it!

This recipe sounded like a great idea for the party I was planning. I decided to try it out before the party, to make sure it works. Good thing, I did! And twice! First time I followed the recipe exactly but by accident put the oven on 300 degrees, instead of 350 - it came out juicy inside but too pale and soggy outside. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was soooo goood!! I love to cook and as I've gotten older I rarely measure but did follow the basics of this since I adjusted this for 2 servings. I heated basil infused oil and about the same amount of butter and finely diced garlic. When cool I added a good squeeze of lemon and dredged the chicken breasts in it and then in the breadcrumb mixture of Parmesan, pepper and some Lawry's Seasoned Salt. I baked it on a rack like someone else suggested at 425. It came out a little crunchy, and still very moist inside. It pared up very well with Easy Lemon and Garlic Broccoli also from this site. What a lovely dinner we had!!! Thanks Karen.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4277162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one for your keeper file and really no need to make changes!  I used panko crumbs but that's personal preference, I like the crunch. My chicken breasts were thick so I cut in half through the sides, which gave me two large, yet thinner, pieces of chicken.  This saved me from the bother of pounding (which I avoid because the chicken juices splat out, even if they are sandwiched in wax paper) plus it's faster.  I also cooked the cutlets on my cookie cooling racks in the sheet pan, to keep the meat crispier. (A good trick when cooking with fattier meats, too, to keep meat leaner).  And finally, I had three chicken breasts for 7 people and because I'd cut them in in half thinly and they still looked full-sized to the diners they felt full and I still had leftovers!

dateLastModified:
2011-11-28T19:08:57.64

userID:
3855165
Display Name:
Dawn Kent
isPro:
False
followersCount:
20

0

9
favoritesCount:
142
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4026405.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I kinda changed the recipe up a little for more taste. I used about 1/2 bulb fresh chopped garlic, with about 2 tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil(for sauteing and taste), Then I used about 1c italian breadcrumbs, about 1/2c parm cheese, about 1 tablespoon garlic powder, some salt, pepper and a pinch of red pepper flakes. 
*Most of those ingredients were eyeballed* Then about 5 minutes before chicken was done, I added some mozz cheese along with a mexican blend then about 2 minutes later, I added a little of the customized store bought sauce to each then baked for another 3 minutes. 
Served with customized store bought sauce over linguine and fettuccine. Absolutely amazing!
*Picture in Photo section*

Rating:
3

text:
Amazing!  Basicallly followed the recipe exactly, but finely minced the garlic instead of crushing.  The garlic & butter really only coated 3 big breast halves, so would suggest doubling for six.  Used Panko crumbs as one review suggested and romano (which I like better than parmesan).  Cooked about 40 minutes.  Incredibly tasty for something so simple.  Moist, tender and brimming with a good flavor.  It's a keeper!

I've always tried to get my baked chicken and I this recipe did it with a few minor changes. Instead of olive oil, I used to eggs to save calories and fat in the meal. I added the salt, pepper and basil to the eggs and coated the chicken with this before I coated them in the bread crumb and parmesan mixture. Like others, I used Panko crumbs. I believe this was the key to the chicken's crunchiness! Great recipe overall! Definitely a staple

This was a great recipe, but I changed a couple of things myself.  First I infused the garlic and the oil by cooking the garlic in the oil until it was clear, then let it cool.  You can store this in the fridge and also use it for dipping bread.
     Then I used some home made garlic and butter crutons instead of plain crackers.  But I did try it the orginal way first and it was delicious.

None
text:
this was really yummy!   i modified it a bit and it turned out really good.   i pounded the chicken breasts a bit thinner to about 3/8 inch since they were almost 1" thick and then marinated overnight in olive oil, about 3 tbsp chopped garlic from a jar, basil and some honey mustard dressing.  i didn't measure out any of the bread crumb mixture but eyeballed it and it looked good and it turned out fantastic and i baked it about 40 minutes.  was super moist and very tasty.  my husband and sons liked it and they had it with honey mustard dressing on top/side.  i served it with garlic buttered pasta and green beans and rolls.  nice change of pace.  thank you - have added this to my recipe box!  :)

None
text:
This was surprisingly good for such a simple dish.  I appreciated not having to flour and egg the chicken, a process that I find tedious, and this dish offers the added benefit of being baked instead of fried.  I used home-made bread crumbs from half a loaf of stale bread.  I didn't measure the olive oil, but I definitely used more than 2 tablespoons;  I just added it to the dish with the garlic as it got used up.  I baked it at 160°C for 40 minutes.  Perfect.

text:
A great and easy recipe. I substitued the olive oil for 1 tablespoon Roasted Garlic Avocado Oil and 1 tablespoon Tuscan Herb Avocado Oil for a mouthwatering result! Avo oil has a high smoke point, over 500 degrees, so there's no burning or smoking at high temps and you don't lose the infused flavors.

text:
Amazing! Really great! Instead of putting pepper in the breading, i salted and peppered the chicken. I then dipped it in the oil/garlic and breading mixture just like the recipe. I also added onion powder and oregano to the mixture. I piled extra breading below and on top of the chicken. After that, I sprinkled a little more dried basil and oregano as well as garlic powder. I used tinfoil for easy cleanup and tented it in the beginning, but as I got impatient, I folded it down.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is similar to what we've been making for years: used 1/2 dijon mustard and 1/2 oil, omit basil, 2/3 c parsley, 3 cloves garlic and freshly-shredded parmesan. If using panko/bread crumbs with no seasoning be sure to add pepper and salt to taste (careful with the salt if using fresh parmesan)  Whirl everything except oil/mustard in food processor starting with garlic/parsley. Can make in bulk and freeze.   Tried and true. Next time I'll try it with some fresh basil!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe.  My husband and I both really enjoyed it.  I used shredded Parmesan, since that's what I keep on hand.  I used 4 large chicken breasts, & it seemed like I had way too many breadcrumbs and not enough olive oil, using the recipe proportions.  There was only enough oil to dip one side of each piece of chicken, but that was enough to provide great flavor.  I used a garlic press instead of mincing the garlic, & that worked very nicely.  Next time I would reduce the breadcrumbs to equal the cheese, when using 4 chicken breasts.  The chicken turned out moist and flavorful.  I appreciate the simplicity of the recipe.  It's a definite keeper.  Thanks!  I will be making this again.

text:
AMAZINGLY delicious! I just made a few additions to make this similar to traditional chicken parmesan: I added an extra 20 minutes to the recipe since my chicken wasn't even close to done at the time stated! I spooned about a cup of garlic pasta sauce over the top of the chicken breasts about 10 min before the chicken was done cooking. And the last 2 minutes or so, I put two pieces of sliced provolone on top and let it melt. I served with spaghetti tossed with pesto and grated parmesan. Its amore!!! I'll definitely make again. OUTSTANDING

text:
This is WOW level chicken...  something I would be proud to serve to guests.  A bonus is the taste is no reflection on how quick and easy this dish is to prepare!  I personally used roasted garlic instead of minced in the olive oil and Italian bread crumbs with a sprinkle of salt, pepper, and garlic salt, along with the parmesean cheese and basil.  Using bowls worked great, I mixed the dry ingredients well in a plastic bag and only added 1/3 at a time to the bowl to keep them fresh and not clumping as I breaded more chicken.  ABSOLUTELY SUPERB!!!  Need to find a good side dish to go with it, 'plain' spaghetti doesn't quite fit right?  Maybe a dressed up potato recipe...

text:
I made this as is except that I had only 1/4 cup of bread crumbs left and made up the difference with panko bread crumbs (used 3/4 cup). It was tasty and crispy. I think I'll make it like this next time I want baked chicken cutlets. The flavors meld together nicely without overpowering each other. It will be my new go-to for a healthier option. I agree with another reviewer that mentioned that 2 tablespoons of olive oil for coating will not be enough to cover 6 cutlets. I would say 2 tablespoons of oo will cover approximately 3 chicken breasts. Also, I might use a ratio of 2 garlic cloves to 2 tablespoons of oo only because my family likes garlic. Do not pass up this recipe...it's worth it!!!

text:
Oh my god this was so good. I made it last night, and I only changed a few things - one, I used panko bread crumbs as recommended. DO THIS, it gives it a wonderful crunch. Two- I added a teaspoon of oregano to the cheese/breadcrumb mix. Three, at the end of thirty minutes it didn't seem quite done (I also forgot to set a timer in the beginning) so I cranked the heat to broil for five minutes and it lightly toasted the breadcrumbs and gave it a lovely crust. Perfect!

text:
I have made this more than once, and my husband and adult children love it!  I did change in that I use italian bread crumbs instead of using basil and black pepper. I have also substituted Italian Cheese shreds (mix of mozarella, provolone and parmesan)which reduces cost minimally but returns awesome flavor. This reheats well.  Last time I used boneless skinless thighs as well as breasts and the results were outstanding.  No waste if you make extra because it reheats well.  My hubby said make this again!!

This was great.  I agree with other viewers that the quantities are skewed.  I used 1/2 c bread crumbs and 1/3 c of parm cheese and still had plenty left over.  I skipped the basil as we didn't have any and the pepper as my husband doesn't like it.  I did use seasoned bread crumbs and with the garlic, I thought this was a nice amount of seasoning.  Very simple recipe and my 4 year old loved it which makes it AMAZING!!!

SeeJae

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pretty good! Followed the directions. The garlic clove bits didn't really stick to the chicken at all, so I might try garlic powder or salt next time. Also, the Parmesan cheese we used (just pre-shredded stuff in a plastic bottle) hardened a little bit after the baking, so we got a few bites that were quite crunchy from the cheese. Also, we used crushed up Ritz crackers instead of bread crumbs, because we can never find bread crumbs in the store. Still delicious with the minor change! But overall, it was a really good recipe, great tasting! Highly recommend it! (EDIT: Okay, I made it again using 1 tsp garlic salt in the dry mixture instead of garlic clove w/ olive oil. It turned out much better. Recommend it if you find the garlic is not sticking to your chicken!)

Overall this recipe was easy  and delicious to make. I would definitely make it again.

text:
No changes needed, moist & tender and ready for your favorite sauce or salad dressing. There is a baked chicken nugget recipe that is very similar and equally good. The idea is a chicken that will please little ones who want to put ketchup or ranch dressing on and big one who like to use hot wing or bbq sauce.  It is a wonderful and versatile chicken. 

I did actually use "seasoned" chicken breasts from the deli counter but since I loathe people who give a good review only after changing the entire recipe, I only mention it in case, like me, it happens to be what you have on hand.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was tasty, as long as you add your own flavor since not everyone likes the same thing. I too thought the breadcrumbs left over was waaaaaaaaayy too much, even for 6 pieces of chicken, I had to scrape some off before serving to my kids. So here's what I did for the oil and garlic mix: for every 3 pieces, I used 2 tablespoons of oil and 1 clove (equaling 4 tablespoons of oil and 2 cloves of garlic), it was enough then. I also added garlic powder, savory seasoning and paprika for a little more flavor. I gave this 5 stars because after you put your own spin on it, it will be a hit, as it was with my picky 4 and 2 yr old.

text:
Delicious! ... but with a few changes from reviews I read, so I gave it 4 stars instead of 5. 
I put the garlic in the oil as recipe states, but also added 2 more cloves into the breading mix along with a little salt. (we love garlic!)
I also turned the temp up a bit after realizing it just wasn't going to brown/crisp like I wanted it to on the outside before the inside dried out. 
I served this with a small side of spaghetti sauce for dipping. I am looking forward to using this recipe as a base for chicken Parmesan...yum!

text:
It was a tasty chicken breast, but nothing to wave flags over. I made it as the recipe states. If I make it again, I'll season the breast (S&P) before I dip it in the olive oil and garlic and I will add, probably, some Italian Seasoning and a bit of white pepper to the bread crumbs and probably some dried parsley. Or maybe start with Italian bread crumbs. I will also give the coated breasts a fine mist of olive oil spray oil. Or coat my hands with olive oil and just pat them a bit.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1019620.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe mentioned that the chicken should be baked in the oven for thirty minutes. My biggest concern was the chicken becoming too dry while baking in the oven. I cooked the chicken in a skillet with some olive oil and garlic, for about fifteen to twenty minutes, and the chicken was moist. Also, I substituted Italian bread crumbs because it had more flavor in it. I served the chicken with Caesar's salad, and I was able to serve dinner within half an hour. I will continue to keep making this recipe, but I will cook the chicken over the stove than to bake it. :-)

text:
This was very good.  I didn't make HUGE adjustments, just very small ones, using the same ingredients.  I toasted 3 slices of white bread for the bread crumbs and processed in the food processor with the cheese, basil, pepper.  I used 4 or so cloves of garlic instead of 1...we really like garlic. I also followed a suggestion in the comments to allow the garlic to soak in the oil to get the flavor going.  I prepared the oil, then peeled and chopped potatoes for mash potatoes, and trimmed the chicken while the garlic oil was "brewing", about 15 minutes or so.  I am not sure what a difference that made to the flavor, but what can it hurt right?

text:
Fantastic Recipe but I changed a few things to make it perfect!! Instead of chicken I used Veal! Yum.  Use Lard instead of olive oil because it gives it that Spanish tamale kick.  Deef fried 1st before baking, so you can stuff the veal with Mayo (I used miracle whip though).  Dry bread crumbs seemed lame so I used Spicy Italalian dried crumbs, portabella mushrooms, goat cheese and a touch of Dr Pepper in the stuffing.  Oh and some Bruschetta (optional) Wrapped these fried, stuffed, chicken rolls in kale (seaweed) topped with about 1 cup romano/mozzarella after dipping in egg white and bake.  Its that easy.  Family loved it, dogs too!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was awesome! The only changes I made was to the type of bread crumbs: I used Stoffer's Stove Top stuffing (Chicken) and using a rolling pin crushed the amount that i needed for the breading. I also added about a 1/2 cup of shredded cheese to the breading mixture (either Sharp Cheddar, three cheese mix, or Mozzarella....all three types of cheese work great so take your pick.) 
I did notice that if you add the extra ingredient you'll have to decrease the amount of bread crumbs from 1 cup to about 1/2 to 3/4 cup depending on the size of the chicken breasts.

None
text:
This recipe was good, but it took about 45 min in my oven at 350F to reach an internal temp of 165. Also, she instructs to top the chicken with any remaining crumbs, but this resulted in a lot of dry crumbs in our mouths. Since there is no egg to create a coating, the extra crumbs don't really combine into the crust. Only the crumbs closest to the oil coating stick. So I won't be adding the additional crumbs on top next time. Otherwise, a tasty and very moist baked chicken recipe overall. Next time I'll add some oregano and salt for additional flavor and some dried parsley for additional color. My husband liked it enough as is for a thumbs up. Thanks, Karen!

text:
the taste was incredibly delicious. I used skinless boneless chicken thighs - I love dark meat and the texture much better because it is more juicy and tender. I used panko breadcrumbs for a better crunch and I omitted the clove of garlic and just lightly sprinkled some s&p and garlic powder onto the chicken itself before dipping in oil. I also omitted the basil - just for personal preference. However, next time I will dip the chicken in a whisked egg mixture instead of the oil - I found that dipping them in olive oil did not make the breadcrumbs stick at all.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This chicken was great! I didn't follow the recipe exactly, just kind of borrowed the general idea. I used two cloves of garlic (we love garlic at my house). I also just kind of estimated the ratios of seasoned bread crumbs to the shaky Parmesan cheese. I cooked at 350 degrees for a little longer than recommended (they still looked pink to me). and MAN were they good! I usually use egg and milk to bread my chicken, and I'm sure olive oil is less healthy but it was so much crispier on the breading. Also, if you use 2 cloves, don't be scared by the overpowering scent of garlic that will be in your kitchen while these are cooking... the taste isn't overpowering at all, it's just right! I highly recommend this for an easy week night dinner idea.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pretty juicy.   I began with chicken breasts bone in, skin on-so cut off pieces of chicken (like chicken tenders).  I stuck it in a ziplock with 2 crushed garlic cloves and 4 TBL olive oil.  Threw in some cayenne, white pepper, and garlic salt.  Marinated for about 9 hours.  Then, when I prepared to bake it- preheated oven to 350, greased the dish, and crushed some colby cheez-its (9) with the  1/2 cup italian bread crumbs, 1/3 cup jack cheese, and  1/3 mexican blend cheese.  Added  some basil, mixed it- dipped the chicken-and stuck it in the oven :)  ENJOY!!!

text:
Baked Garlic Parmesan Chicken Haiku: "So easy to make. And the taste was excellent. But too many crumbs." I hated having to toss so much extra of the crumb mixture, but there was just alot leftover, even after following the recipe saying to top the chicken w/ what remained. But otherwise, the resulting chicken was moist and wonderfully seasoned, although it just occured to me that I used Italian Seasoned breadcrumbs, as that's all I had available. Oh and to avoid mushy chicken, I baked it on a greased rack over a pan to catch anything, flipping half-way thru. Got that tip from another baked chicken from AR.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4004706.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this tonight for supper and it was fantastic, pleasing even the picky eaters :) My only adjustments were to use the pre-seasoned Italian chicken breasts (from Walmart) and then I doubled the breading, using Panko crumbs and adding a tsp. of oregano in addition to the basil as well as 1/4 cup of shredded mozzarella cheese. I had to increase my baking time by about 15 minutes just because the chicken breasts were quite large but the chicken was very moist, not dried out at all. I will definitely be making this again!

I made this tonight and it was very delicious.  The chicken was moist and very tender.  Instead of the grated Parmesan cheese I used a shredded 3 Italian cheese made up of Parmesan, Asiago, and Romano. text:
This was delicious!! I had 10 half chicken breasts, lots of hungry people! The only thing I did was add Emerils chicken rub to the oil and garlic and did 2 garlic cloves.  Had  to use a little more oil obviously, and added a tbsp. of seasoned salt and a tsp. of Italian seasoning to the Italian bread crumb mixture. Which I put in a freezer bag and used like shake and bake. I sprinkled a little left over crumb mixture not all just enough to give it a little more crust.  This got terrific reviews from everybody and there was only one little piece left over that my husband hid in the fridge for his lunch.  Tender and juicy and will definitely make again.  Thanks for the recipe!

This is a wonderful recipe.  Being a garlic-Parmesan lover, I used 10 finely minced cloves of garlic in several tablespoons of olive oil and matched the amount of freshly-grated Parmesan cheese with Italian bread crumbs.  I coated 8 chicken breasts very generously with the mixture and distributed all of the leftover minced garlic amongst the chicken breasts.  Baked as directed.  My kids said it was the best garlic-Parmesan chicken I have ever made. It was definitely superb.

I found this recipe so simple and easy to throw together on a busy weeknight!

I had nothing prepared for dinner and had to come up with something quick using only ingredients on hand. It turned out great.. only changes were using Italian style bread crumbs, baking for an additional 1/2 hr (bone in chicken) and topped with salsa and mozz. cheese for the last 10 minutes.

text:
Excellent recipe! The chicken came out really moist and the flavors all went together wonderfully. I made it with fusilli, tomato sauce, and cheesy garlic bread, which went together with the chicken really well.

I would recommend getting smaller chicken breast halves in you can, though. I bought five large ones and it was almost enough for two meals [mind you, I made it for four people]. This also meant that it had to be in the oven for longer than 30 minutes as the recipe suggests.

But overall, this recipe is a keeper! : )

userID:
2891016
Display Name:
FutureStevenson
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
4
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The dish was very good. I did do some things differently. I seasoned the chicken first with pepper, salt, adobo, and sazon. I also mixed the oil with garlic, and a dash of salt and pepper, and put it in the microwave for about 30 secs., so it can really blend together. I did not have any basil, so i substituted for oregano. I did not dip the chicken in the oil, but i did use a brush, which was perfect. While chicken cooking in oven, every 15 minutes i flipped the chicken so it would not get  wet at bottom. The chicken came out perfect juicy inside not dry at all and crispy on out. i had to cook the chicken for 45 minutes, due to the size of the breast. I also topped it off w/ a salad of mixed greens,  tomatoes, red onions, kalamata  olives and balsamic vinaigrette. From the words of my husband, "Baby, you got to make this again for my business dinner!"

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy recipe.  Mine came out very tender and juicy after I made a few minor modifications: 1. Pounded the chicken breasts to flatten out a bit. 2. Seasoned the chicken with poultry seasoning, garlic powder and Italian seasoning. 3. Marinated the chicken in buttermilk for about 90 minutes. (Even tossed a little spice in the marinade for grins.) 4. Blended the garlic cloves and olive oil together in a mini-food processor. 5. Used Panko bread crumbs. I definitely will make this again. We served with a side dish of noodles and alfredo sauce.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very good.  I varied the directions slightly by omitting the olive oil/garlic mixture to dip it in.  Instead, I patted the chicken breasts & dipped them in flour (with a little salt, pepper, and a touch of italian seasoning), then dipped them in beaten eggs, then dipped them in the bread crumb mixture.  I also added a little bit of garlic powder to the bread crumb mixture.  Turned out great with the linguini and spaghetti sauce we had with it.  Very easy.  It doesn't get 5 stars because as one reviewer said, it wasn't "knock your socks off" good, but it was very good.

text:
This was definitely an easy recipe made for those nights when you really don't want to spend too much time in the kitchen. LOVE THAT! Only problem I found was that the chicken either needed to be browned in a pan first, or thrown in the broiler for a minute or two at the end to brown/crispen up the breading. Without that it was still fairly dry and mushy. Will make again, possibly just on the stovetop next time.

I just made this and it was excellent. I made alot more of the oil garlic mixture then called for(but I LOVE garlic) and also took another members advice and used a brush to brush on the mixture (I also added parmesan cheese to the oil.) for about the last 10 min I put on the broiler and it really helped crisp up the chicken. I think next time I will use more parm cheese then breadcrumbs...delicious.

text:
This was very easy to make.  I was in charge of cooking dinner for 12 people on a ski trip in a cabin and this was VERY easy to make.  I took the oil and garlic with me.  I took the breading mixture already mixed in a ziploc bag and a bag of frozen chicken breasts from Costco.  They thawed out pretty quickly and I baked them on a cookie sheet I brought with me.  It was SO easy.  Everyone loved them!  I served it with some spaghetti and garlic bread and we had a feast!

Display Name:
Denise

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/959958.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Here is another review that changes the recipe a bit!  I note the changes because it allows me to repeat what I did when I first prepared this dish AND I view recipes as a starting off point when I head to the kitchen.  I took 2 boneless chicken breasts and cut them into chunks.  I mixed about a 1/2 cup gf seasoned crumbs and 1 cup of parmesan in a plastic bag and tossed in the chicken.  I let it sit in the fridge for about 3 hours.  Meanwhile, I cooked sliced garlic and onion in an oven safe skillet and set it aside.  I put mushrooms in the bottom of the skillet, put the chicken in and topped with the cooked garlic and onion and topped with the crumbs and cheese.  I sprinkled a bit of olive oil over all and baked for 30 minutes at 350 degrees.  I'll certainly make this again with changes:  chicken thighs, halved mushrooms and a bit of broth/white wine in the bottom of the skillet prior to baking.  I also thought these chunks of chicken would be delightful in a sub sandwich topped with red pasta sauce!
Review:
Rating:
1

text:
I added a little bit to this recipe, which may have made it taste above and beyond and make me want to keep eating it! I used fresh basil and added fresh oregano as well, used an egg wash instead of olive oil, added salt and the garlic to the dry ingredients, and brined the chicken. Brining chicken makes a huge difference and keeps it moist and flavorful after cooking. I also used thighs instead of breasts (because sales), but I don't know how much that contributed to the overall flavor.

Did not make any changes and it was wonderful. Made double recipe and froze 1/2 of the cooked recipe. When time to fix it 3 weeks later I thawed out the cooked chicken bread wrapped on counter. When ready to warm for supper, I wrapped It loosely in aluminum foil and parchment paper  and warmed it at 350 for 35 minutes / even better than first portion. A definite repeat dinner at our house! Wonderful with corn on the cob!!!!!

Easy delicious recipe.  I did make a change, instead of using olive oil I used zesty Italian salad dressing and dipped the chicken breasts first then coated with crumbs.  For crumbs, I used half crushed garlic/butter croutons, and other half homemade croutons.  I had made an Italian baked potato medley side dish. I would change my side dish to a bed of ziti noodles and marinara sauce sprinkled with fresh parmesan.  I will be making this again.

text:
This is one of my family’s favorite recipes. The kids and their significant others always ask if I’m making ‘that chicken’ when they come home to visit. You can hear a pin drop as they devour it!  I cut up & pound out the chicken so it’s tender. I put the basil & pepper in with the oil and garlic. I also dice up potatoes and either broccoli or asparagus. I arrange it around the chicken and you have a full meal. NOTE: I use a cookie sheet with sides. When cutting & pounding out chicken, you end up with a lot more!

userID:
24750766
Display Name:
Tesunie Kataren
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6125123.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A very good recipe, when you avoid some simple to do mistakes. Some of the common mistakes I saw in the reviews were:
- Mushy: If you flipped it during cooking, you would probably get a mushy crust top. Don't flip it if you want the breading to crisp! (AKA: Don't flip it, the recipe doesn't call for it.)
- Took longer to cook: Most likely, these reviewers cooked full chicken breasts, rather than halves. This could also lead to other issues. Cut thicker pieces into smaller pieces, so they will cook better.
- Ran out of... : As above with took too long to cook, these people most likely tried cooking too large of pieces of chicken. Though, I will note now that I found there was just the right amount of olive oil mixture for four half breasts, maybe five. So I do recommend a little more oil mixture for any more than 5 half breasts being prepared.
- Flavorless: These people probably did not add in enough herbs to their mixture. Use what style of breadcrumbs you like. I personally used what I had on hand, Italian seasoned breadcrumbs. I have also found that I've always liked anything breaded like this to have half breadcrumbs and half Panko as I like a little extra crunch. These should not have had enough of a change to the recipe to make much note. (Also, add in any extra breading mix right to the top of the chicken before cooking.)

My only strong note might be, despite everything else being great, possibly to cook it at 375 degrees F for a little more browned top crust.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-12-16T22:59:15.88
helpfulCount:

Made only 4 breasts, but did not adjust recipe size. I did not have enough parm. to do the recipe, so I used 1/2 low fat/moisture mozzarella and pulsed in bullet to make a uniform crumble. This was a great go-to when my dinner plans fell through. Simple, quick and delish! The only thing I changed was using thin cut chicken breast because we are not fans of the thick type. Made 2 packages of 1 1/3 lbs each, baked for 10, then broil for 3 to crisp them up. Family of 4 with 2 teens, I have 3 remaining pieces...will add to salad for lunches!  Would be a great way to make a quick Chicken Parm with sauce, too!

text:
Super easy and delicious recipe as written.  The second time I made it, I used thyme instead of basil, added a few lemon slices and butter to the bottom of a cast iron skillet.  I placed the breaded chicken on top of the lemon/butter combo, threw in a couple of sprigs of thyme and baked at 350 until done.  I was then able to use the drippings to make a thin-ish gravy/sauce.  Served with either mashed potatoes or rice - my family loves it!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was so easy and delicious! Some notes: I salted and peppered my chicken breasts and marinated them in chopped garlic and olive oil for a couple hours prior. Then, I let the breasts get back up to room temperature before breading them with the breadcrumb mixture. I added some panko bread crumb to mine to add extra crunch. I baked the breasts on a pan with a rack because I was worried they would be soggy in a dish. They turned out amazing!!! I also recommend pounding the chicken breasts flat before cooking so they don't take as long. Our air chilled chicken breasts from H-E-B were huge so they took the full 40 mins. Definitely would make this again!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2017-11-11T01:02:13.37
helpfulCount:
0

text:
Very tasty dish... I made this tonight for my wife and myself, along with some mashed cauliflower & carrot sticks. The only changes I made to the original recipe were in quantities. As I was preparing dinner for only two people, I used an 8"x8" pyrex pan for 2 boneless chicken breasts. I also reduced the ingredients for the breading mixture... time in oven was the same, 30 minutes @ 350 degrees. The chicken was cooked through and still very moist. Super pleased with how the dish turned out, we will surely be having this again.

Only thing- next time I will cut the bread crumb mixture in half.

text:
This recipe was great. I didn't have quite enough parmesan on hand, but it still turned out really well. We used panko crumbs instead of bread crumbs because they were cheaper. (Panko crumbs are tougher so that may also help with the sogginess other reviewers talked about.) We paired it with cheese tortellini, spaghetti sauce, and a side of broccoli. We also made extra breaded chicken and froze them individually, which has been really convenient. My husband loves this recipe so we'll definitely make it again!

text:
The chicken that this recipe makes is a little bit bland, to be very honest with you, as I have made it without revisions once. That being said, I'd highly recommend beginning with these ingredients as a base, adding garlic powder or garlic salt (depending on how salty you'd like your chicken), dried minced onions, and substituting Italian herb bread crumbs instead of the normal ones. This makes for more flavorful chicken. Hope it helps!

text:
Excellent recipe. I cooked the dinner around the requirements of this recipe reduced for 2 breasts (i.e., reduced chicken coating amt proportionally). I set the oven to 400 then put 2 baker potatoes in for 10 mins. I then reduced the temp to 350 and put two breasts in an oiled casserole in for 40 mins. I then put 2 servings of asparagus spears, oiled, peppered and seasoned with garlic salt, around the breasts, then put everything back in for 12 mins. Everything came out done perfectly for my wife and me.

text:
Very very good!  I pretty much followed the recipe exactly.  The only difference for me was a longer cooking time.  After the 30 minutes, it didn't look done to me so I added another 10 minutes and watched for the juice to run, which it did.  It was perfectly tender and juicy!  We all know different ovens behave differently, so just be mindful and make sure it's done before you pull it out.

text:
I made this for my husband and 7 year old son and they LOVED it - you know it's good when they ask for more. The chicken came out moist, flavorful and the bread crumbs added an extra texture. I made a few tweaks given the review feedback - I used 4 tspn olive oil, 2 minced garlic, salt and pepper and also seasoned the chicken with a seasoning salt. For the crumb, I mixed Italian seasoning bread crumbs with panko Japanese style bread crumbs. It came out so delicious we've decided to make it for dinner with risotto this weekend with some guests. Thanks for the great and oh-so easy recipe.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2853281.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed a few of the other reviewers tips: 1) pounded the chicken breasts so they were even thickness (mine were pretty big so they needed to be flattened to cook more evenly).  2) used fresh Parmesan. 3) added grated mozzarella at the end and broiled a couple of minutes - would still have been good without this step added, in my opinion.   I cooked at 350 for about 20 minutes and upped it to 375 for another 10 minutes, broiled for 5 w/the added cheese, and it came out beautifully moist and delicious.

I have to say, my hubby and son both loved it.  My 13yr old typically turns his nose up to chicken, but this time, he went back for seconds, and even told me he wanted leftovers the next day.  That is saying a lot coming from him!

text:
This was amazing! The first time I tried this recipe I followed it to the tee and couldn't get enough. The times since I made it I tweaked a couple things and it was still amazing. I now use Italian breadcrumbs, fresh minced garlic instead of store bought minced, and depending on the day I add a teaspoon or so of cayenne pepper or Italian seasoning, or whatever flavor spice I want that night. I also started to used boneless, skinless, chicken tenders instead of breasts so I have more chicken and for leftovers they work great in wraps/subs/or pasta. This is a have to try recipe for sure!!!!!!

I have made many versions of this recipe before that were very delicious but typically involved copious amounts of butter. This version replaces the butter with olive oil, which I was skeptical about, and the results are amazing! This chicken could not have been more moist and delicious!!! I did add a bit more olive oil and then scraped the remaining oil and garlic into the pan and added the rest of the bread crumb mixture on top of the chicken before baking. 30 minutes was right on the nose and it was just perfect!

text:
Absolutely delicious!!  Changed it up a bit thanks to some previously posted suggestions.  Easy clean-up when you put the chicken, olive oil (6 tbsp) and garlic (2 1/2 tsp) in a sealable bag - then put it in the breadcrumb mixture.  Used whole wheat seasoned breadcrumbs and freshly grated Parmesan.  Baked 8 chicken breasts at 375 degrees for 40 minutes and they came out juicy and quite tasty.  Easy and quick recipe!  A must have in my recipe box now!

country:
None
text:
Made the recipe exactly as written and it was just OK for us. Wait...I did use italian seasoned bread crumbs (gluten free) since I didn't have plain on hand. The ratio of oil to garlic for dipping the chicken breasts in was not enough. Scaled the recipe to 3 breasts and if I were to make this again, I would double the oil and garlic cloves and add salt and pepper to the chicken breasts or bread crumbs. Otherwise, this seemed more on the bland side (chicken coated in only bread crumbs) and very well could be due to gluten free bread crumbs--thankful they were italian seasoned and not plain. Regular (non gluten free) bread crumbs probably contain a lot of extra ingredients, such as salt or msg. Sorry, but this just wasn't for us in comparison to other similar recipes.

text:
Great starting point of a recipe.  Like others, I made some adjustments - adding Stovetop Chicken Stuffing to the breadcrumbs adds a lot to the taste.  Using more olive oil helps binding everything to the chicken breasts.

Six chicken breasts cooked in a oven-dish took 60mins to cook through.  The chicken was still moist and very tasty. 

Passed the "kid test" with flying colours!

userID:
11760799
Display Name:
LeleW
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can't wait to make this again. Super-super-easy and quick. My husband loved it as well.

To my point...I took the one reviewer up on her suggestion and used the seasoned panko bread crumbs that I had on hand. I had no Parmesan, but did have grated Pecorino Romano. Unfortunately, I *totally* forgot to mix it with the crumbs before putting the chicken in the oven - so about halfway through the cooking time (when I remembered that), I sprinkled the PR on top of each piece. 

I don't do white meat (blah!), so used boneless, skinless chicken thighs - so nice and flavorful. I also was - don't ask me how - out of basil, so threw some poultry seasoning, salt and pepper in with the bread crumbs.

The chicken came out cooked perfectly and *so* good. 

NEXT TIME....I want to try the one reviewer's suggestion about using Pepperidge Farm herb stuffing mix instead of the bread crumbs. I will also try the other suggestion about baking it on a cooling rack and turning it halfway through to keep the breading crispy. But I will *definitely* make it again...

Finally, I agree with the negative reviewer's comment that the recommended amount of olive oil isn't close to enough. So use more!
Review:

5

Display Name:
LeleW

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used boneless, skinless chicken thighs because I can't stand white meat. I took the advice of a couple of other reviewers and (1) used seasoned panko instead of bread crumbs, (2) added a little melted butter to the olive oil, (3) used a little more garlic, (4) baked it on a cooling rack so the chicken wouldn't cook in its own juices and get the breading soggy and (5) baked it at 375 for 30 minutes. The only thing I wouldn't do again is doubling the garlic; it came out a little too strong (and I like garlic). Other than that, it was a very nice recipe and the chicken came out incredibly moist.
Review:
Rating:
2

text:
Absolutely loved this.  I used Stove Top Chicken Flavor for the breading.  I crushed it a little in a plastic bag, added garlic powder, and basil and shook the chicken in the bag to coat.  I rubbed the chicken with garlic oil before putting in the bag.  Next time I may use a combination of melted butter and garlic oil.  I sprinkled all of the leftover crumbs on the top and it came out crunch and delicious.  Some of the best chicken I ever ate.  I did use a little extra parmesan.  I used the canned Parmesan.

text:
Very, very tasty! The cooking temp/time was perfect (always my biggest concern when cooking new dishes), and the chicken was wonderfully moist. I didn't have quite as big a problem with soggy breading as some people seem to have had. 

I will say this: This dish needs WAAAAAAY more garlic to use that word in the recipe title! I only made two servings, but knowing my personal taste I used the whole clove and topped the breasts with the leftover garlic/oil mix. I can't imagine how little garlic flavor there would be if I had made the full six servings! But hey, I'm a garlic lover, so I'm biased.

text:
With modifications for flavor, my husband and I thought this dish was very good!  I substituted Pepperidge Farm Herb Stuffing for the plain breadcrumbs and added 1 teaspoon oregano in addition to the basil leaves.  Used 4 tablespoons olive oil and 2 cloves of garlic.  I sprinkled salt and pepper on chicken breasts prior to coatings.  Also sprinkled garlic powder on top of dish before placing in oven.  I did bake at 350 F for 40-45 minutes.  Chicken was very moist.  Will make again!

A crowd pleaser, easy to make and delicious!
I had found another recipe that is just about the same as this one but uses melted butter rather than olive oil, so between that recipe in my memory and this one here,  it is a fabulously moist, and flavorful dish. I use herb seasoned bread crumbs,  or panko, lots of minced garlic, fresh parmesan cheese a must, and the butter, while decadent, really makes it mouth watering.

text:
I don't usually write reviews, but this was so easy and good that  I had to share. I followed this recipe exactly as it is with 2 exceptions. I used a little more than 2 tbsp of evoo and used more than just 1 clove of garlic. The key to this recipe is to bake it on a cooling rack set on top of a cookie sheet to catch the crumbs and extra oil. Turn them halfway and they will be crispy and not get soggy on the bottom. I also used organic chicken breasts. I've never made chicken that literally melted in my mouth! It was delicious!

text:
This was fantastic!  I followed the advice to place the chopped garlic in some olive oil in the baking dish.  Place it in a low oven for about 10 minutes  to soften the garlic and flavor the olive oil.  Then simply roll the chicken breasts in the garlic oil, coat with the Panko crumb/cheese mixture, and return to the pan to bake. I did use fresh Italian four cheese blend with the Italian Panko crumbs.  I baked at 375 degrees for about 25-30 minutes.  The chicken was very moist and tasted great.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This chicken was so moist!  I didn't have as many chicken breasts as called for in the recipe, but I used close to the same amount of everything else (I reduced the amount of bread crumbs, and added another clove of garlic).  I had just enough olive oil to cover the chicken I had, so I think that if you are using the amount of chicken called for in the recipe, it might be a good idea to increase the amount of oil, as another reviewer had suggested.
Just a heads-up, by adding that extra clove of garlic, I overpowered the dish with garlicky-goodness.  After adding the garlic to the oil, I'd let it sit there for a bit while taking a phone call.  I didn't think that would make it too strong, but I was wrong (think vampire-repellant).  So even though I thought this chicken was great, it ended up being a bit too garlicky for my garlic-loving family.  My 8yo said it was 'too spicy'. 
I'm definitely going to make this dish again, just with less garlic...  :)  Thank you for this recipe!

text:
I added melted butter to the olive oil (about equal amounts), and I used a food processor to blend that with the garlic.  I used slighly more oil and garlic than was recommended to boost the flavor a little and to have a little more oil to work with when I was breading the chicken. 
-I used Panko bread crumbs and FRESH parmesan. 
-I pounded the breasts to ensure even cooking (I cooked them at 375 degrees for 30 minutes).
-Once they were done, I put a little tomato pesto on top of each one and covered that with slices of mozza cheese. I then put the pan under a hot broiler for a minute. 

THESE WERE DELICIOUS  I served them with Orzo pasta and Parmesan asparagus.  YUM!

userID:
10154409
Display Name:
Kimberly Berry
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read many of the reviews before I made this.   They really helped to make this a winning recipe that I made for a luncheon today.  I didn't have Panko bread crumbs so I rolled out garlic croutons, and that worked fine.  I marinated the chicken overnight in Italian salad dressing, with a generous portion of pressed garlic mixed in.  I used parsley, basil and oregano in the bread crumbs.  I put the bread crumbs in a bag and shook a few pieces of meat at a time to coat - so easy.  And very important, I cooked the meat on a cooling rack in a roasting pan.  Extra crumbs I used over the chicken and the rest I froze.   It was a hit.   The crust was crisp, the chicken moist, and it was FULL of flavor.  So marinate the meat, and be sure to use a cooling rack so the crust doesn't get soggy.   I put some mozarella on top after the chicken was done and let it melt in the oven for a short time.  Everyone, including my husband, loved it.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-01-13T11:34:50.327
helpfulCount:
0

text:
This dish was outstanding, a huge hit with the entire family...kids included!  Was so easy to prep & only change that I made was adding a packet of Lipton Dry French Onion which made it crunchy/textured. I removed tin foil the last ten minutes so it wasn't soggy. Made with a side of whole white potatoes cooked in olive oil, butter, salt, pepper, paprika & minced garlic. I have a large family to cook for & have Lupus so it's difficult to make dinners that take along time to prep so this was perfect it fed everyone, only took 10 minutes to prep & 30 min. In the oven. Definetly a favorite & a goto recipe on nights I'm not feeling well.

Display Name:
Morgan Rose
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2727442.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great basic recipe. I think if you follow it to a T then it will a tad tasteless. I used Italian style bread crumbs (all I had) instead of regular bread crumbs. I also didn't have fresh garlic so I used powder. Besides that I followed the recipe exact. I was surprised how moist the chicken was. Everyone loved it. I do suggest using Italian bread crumbs or adding extra italian seasonings. I'm giving this 4 stars because if it wasn't for the extra seasoning it wouldn't have tasted so good. Oh and you will need more than 2 tbs of olive oil. We will be using this as a regular base recipe. So much play room!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
I followed the recipe exactly as it was on here. The chicken was delicious! I used Progresso Italian bread crumbs, fresh ground pepper, extra virgin olive oil, fresh grated parmesan cheese, and Kosher salt. The results were a very juicy inside with a light, crispy coating. I made a marinara sauce to go on top with noodles underneath. The recipe as is, is amazing. I don't think I would change anything other than the bread crumbs in the future just to see what kind of difference that makes. Very low maintenance prep and cook lets you focus on other parts of the meal!

text:
These were very good.  It seems like there is way too much breading, but I followed the recipe and dumped the extra breading on top of the chicken in the pan.  So glad I did - somehow all the extra breading is used up and my kids ate these up, and so did my husband.  I think next time I make this I'll just spray the pan with Pam, sprinkle 1/3 cup of the breading into the pan, lay the chicken breasts on top and then cover with the rest of the breading mix and drizzle with some olive oil.  Easier and less messy way to fix it, and they should still turn out delish.

I made it exactly as the recipe states. I used 6 rather large chicken breasts. The only issue I had was that there was no enough oil/garlic mix to adequately cover all 6 breasts. Added half again as much oil and garlic and it was enough. Suggest you make slightly more than called for.  
It is cooking now. I will add to this after we try it and let you know how it tastes.
It was delicious! Chicken was very moist and could practically be cut with a fork.  Be sure and cover it with foil. It did take slightly longer to cook. Prolly because of the size/number of chicken breasts.
