text:
I made this chicken and followed the recipe exactly. It was very very bland. I noticed the recipe doesn't say to season the chicken first, so as a preventive I used salt and pepper. 

I used seasoned Italian bread crumbs and at 350 for 30 minutes the bread crumbs barely gave a crunch. I'll admit I could definitely taste the Parmesan cheese and garlic, but that was it. (I actually added BBQ Sauce to give it some type of taste) 

If I were to change it any way it would be to make sure to really season the chicken, add panko crumbs instead and cook at 425 for 22 minutes. There are better chicken recipes out there. 

I won't make this again.

This was moist and flavorful. I served it along with garlic and butter new potatoes. I didn't have Italian bread crumbs so I used Panko. I added a few seasonings, dried parsley, oregano and pepper to the Panko. It was wonderful. My bf loved it too. He cleaned his plate of two large pieces. The other thing I changed was the cooking time. Instead of the recommended cooking time of 20 minutes, I cooked it for 26 minutes because I wanted the crust a bit drier and crunchy. I will definitely make this again. Next time though, if I use Panko crumbs, I will add Italian seasoning.

text:
Honest to goodness, I think this is the very best chicken I've ever made.  It was falling apart and SO flavorful.  (I used chicken tenders because they were cheaper, and they worked well.)  There was a ton of breadcrumb mixture left over, and I was nervous about it burning on top, so I only put half of the leftovers on top and threw the rest out.  I don't know what I was thinking!  Next time, I'll use all of it.  Oh--and I used a can of chicken gravy, some simple boiled new potatoes, and corn on the cob to round the meal out.  I was lazy, but everything went together well.

text:
This recipe was well received but not raved about. I did make a couple of additions but nothing that would have changed my mind about the 4 stars. 

My additions: doubled the olive oil and garlic, pounded the chicken flat and added a tsp of oregano.
Changes: used a baggie for the bread crumbs, it is easier for cleanup. Add the oregano when you add the basil. Sprinkled the whole thing with garlic powder. Baked at 40 mins uncovered.

text:
This is an OK recipe.  I set the recipe for 7 servings. I recommend using a little more olive oil then what the recipe calls for, you will run out.  The bread crumb coating was a little soft.  I'm not sure if this is a function of time cooked or heat to get it to be a little more crunchy.  I boiled my chicken breasts for a few minutes before I dipped them in the garlic and olive oil and then breaded them. Baked for 25 minutes.  The chicken was very tender and juicy, but like I said the bread coating was a little soft. I will try this again with some modifications to spice it up.  My kids liked it and that says a lot.

I used this on chicken breasts & legs. I omitted the Parmesan because I realized I had none after I chopped garlic & mixed my bread crumbs with seasoning. I added garlic powder to the bread crumbs for a little more garlic flavor. It turned out great. I use a very similar recipe for baked pork loin except I use Italian seasoning with the bread crumbs and mix it together with the olive oil. Pat the mixture onto the pork loin until it's coated & bake. It's amazing!!!

None
text:
Excellent recipe for easy, delicious chicken. My whole family loves this recipe and said I should make it at least once a week. TIP for cooking chicken: Always use a cooking thermometer. Take it out of the oven check the temperature, and if it's less than 160 deg F, it's not done. In fact for my palate, I like to get the chicken to at least 175-180 deg F as it's tastier. Higher than 190 deg F and it may become dry.

text:
This was very good.  I used breasts and slightly pounded to an even 1/2 inch (they were big).  I marinated in Kraft Zesty Italian for 1/2 hour. Did not dip in any thing, rolled in Panko, Parmesan, Parsley, Lemon Pepper.   Cooked in convection toaster oven.  The last 10mins I poured the oil, garlic mixed with butter over and sprinkled with Paprika.  When tested and were 160 but not brown, turn on the broil for about 5 minutes.  Husband loved and so did I.  Served with mini potatoes which cooked with the chicken and sautéed asparagus.  While almost a new recipe, I would have never put all the together without the base recipe and other suggestions.

userID:
14531581
Display Name:
Isa709
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very yummy recipe! However; i did make some changes it to the original. First of all i marinated my chicken breasts with Tuscan Italian House dressing and milk to make the breasts very tender! I let them marinate for at least 4hrs. Second, i added 1 cup of Panko Bread crumbs and 1 cup of Italian seasoned bread crumbs instead of plain as the recipe called for. I also made 8 breast instead of 6 therefore i had to alter the recipe a bit. I used 5 cloves of garlic that i chopped then crushed - i find that it releases more of the garlic flavor this way- i then followed the directions on the original recipe... Just before putting them into the oven, in my household we like spicy therefore i sprinkled a little bit of Cayenne pepper on top of all breast also garlic powder, onion powder then a dash of  Rosemary! I did the 8 breast at 375 for 30 min, then turned them and did another 10 min. THIS WAS SPECTACULAR!! The parmesan and garlic sure make a great combo! And the Panko addition made this recipe the bomb since they were crispy on the outside but very tender on the inside! Just perfect. I have 2 lil boys and this was devour in minutes! TRY IT OUT

text:
Made this tonight, and per following the directions, was very bland in our opinion. The chicken was a bit dry, although the crunchy topping was crunchy (didn't get soggy like others stated), it just lacked any flavor.  In the future, I will use 4TB oil, & minced garlic not from scratch. I think it would be better if chicken were dipped in oil, & then bread crumb mixture  (and add garlic to the bread crumbs, otherwise they do not stick to the chicken. .hence, the bland flavor).

text:
We really enjoyed this one, but like most, I made modifications.  I seasoned the chicken with kosher salt and ground pepper (light on the salt because of all of the salt in the cheese), and since I didn't have fresh garlic, I also seasoned with garlic powder. Always season your meat at least with salt and pepper before cooking.  I used Progresso Italian Bread Crumbs, which already has some seasoning as well.  I had to use more olive oil than two tablespoons, but I don't know how much more because I just poured a little more in.  It's not a big deal to add a little more.  I didn't have dried basil, but the bread crumbs might have.

While I think this recipe is delicious and I really enjoyed making it, the garlic oil AND bread crumb mixture proportions were off for six breasts. I ended up having to make lots of extra oil mix to cover my chicken, and I had WAY too much bread crumb mix, even after breading all of my chicken and putting some of the mix on top.

text:
Very moist, but not all that delicious, only okay.  For chicken breasts, too many breadcrumbs & not enough oil.  I put the garlic in the oil then removed & saved it.  I dipped the chicken in the garlic oil, coated bottom side of the chicken with crumbs, spooned some garlic on top, then pressed in crumbs.  I was thinking the garlic would stay in the dish or be unevenly distributed - or both.  :D  The crumbs didn't really brown, but that's to be expected without frying.  I'll make some marinara sauce & pasta to go with it tomorrow.

text:
Was looking for a quick, healthy baked chicken breast recipe and this was exactly what I wanted!  It was so easy and the chicken turned out incredibly moist.  I lightly pounded the chicken breasts with a meat tenderizer and substituted with whole wheat breadcrumbs.  As previous reviewers have mentioned, I'll probably try adjusting the recipe by increasing the amount of olive oil & garlic and salt & pepper the chicken before dipping them into the oil mixture next time - but that's just personal preference.  My picky family loved this dish!  (I'm going to try using the leftovers for a chicken parm tomorrow night.)  It requires no flipping in the oven, minimal clean up and it's yummy - you can't ask for a better dish!

userID:
4468752
Display Name:
lucylove
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/746016.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The proportions of olive oil and garlic in this recipe are way off, but the flavor is good.  I could see right away that there wouldn't be enough olive oil and garlic for 6 breasts. 6 cutlets, perhaps. 6 whole breasts? No. I had 2 large chicken breasts and used the recommended oil, but tripled the garlic. It still didn't have a strong garlic flavor, no worries there. (Hint for next time; cook the garlic in the oil first to intensify the flavor) I used ½ cup each plain breadcrumbs and panko, along with the cheese. I baked it in my Breville Smartoven on a raised rack for 35 minutes. again leading me to believe this was written for filleted breasts, not whole ones. The Breville normally DECREASES cooking time. I finished it for 3 minutes under the broiler to brown the coating, then let it rest for 5 minutes.  I'd like to find a way to make the coating adhere better. Dredge them in four before dipping in oil? use less oil, mixed with mayo? Let them chill for an hour? Still, the flavor was still very good and I'd make it again. Served with Pasta e Olio and Caesar Salad Supreme (both on this site) it was a garlic lover's feast. Fix the proportions and timing and it'll be a 5-star Master Recipe. As is, a novice would never get the desired result.
Review:

4

text:
Tried this recipe this evening, and it was very good.  I took the advise of other reviews and prepared less of the bread crumb/parm mixture...  if, after you combine this bread crumbs & cheese mixture and it looks like there's too much, just take some out before breading the chicken...  that way if you've made too much you can always place the unused excess in an airtight container or ziplock, refrigerate it and use it another time, even when making meatballs.  I did use Italian style breadcrumbs and more garlic.

text:
Even my 13yo, who doesn't really like chicken, loved this recipe.  I combined the olive oil & garlic (upped it for 8 boneless breasts) in a ziplock bag & then added the chicken.  I let sit for a few hours in the fridge.  Used italian bread crumbs and Belgiosio shredded parmesan cheese. Baked in oven at 350° for 30 minutes, then 375° for 15 more, since it wasn't cooked enough, according to my meat thermometer (new stove to boot).  Breading was perfect; don't know why some reviews had complained about it being soggy.  DH kept insisting how good the chicken was & even took the leftovers to work the next day.

text:
Made exactly by the recipe. Bland chicken (there's no seasoning on the chicken beyond the garlic), and a mouthful of boring bread crumbs. It might be better with seasoned bread crumbs rather than plain (you have too much dry, flavorless crumbs for the amount of chicken) and with the addition of seasoning to the chicken--and maybe with some sort of wash (besides 2T oil) to make the crumbs stick to the chicken. But as written, this was not very good.

text:
Delicious! It made the whole house smell wonderful. I made some very minor adjustments.  I sliced the chicken breasts, as my family likes their chicken thinner. I really need lots more than 2 tablespoons of olive oil to coat all the chicken and I used lots more garlic too. I also very gently simmered the oil and garlic and then let it sit a few minutes for the oil to really pick up the garlic flavor. I made this recipe twice, once with regular bread crumbs and once with panko. My family preferred the panko style crumbs.Finally, I added some salt and pepper right over the panko coated chicken before putting it in the oven.  An excellent recipe.

text:
I made this tonight. There's nothing amazing about it, but it's a simple, flavorful, and easy dish. I used Panko crumbs like others did, as that's all I really use these days. So much better, and gives recipes more crunch, texture, and a better flavor. I pounded out the chicken a bit to flatten it, and baked it at 375 for 30 minutes, turning the chicken after 15 minutes so each side would crisp up a bit. I'll make it again if I need a quick, healthy dinner in 30 minutes.

text:
I liked this recipe except I modified it a little because I didn't go to the store and sort of had to improvise.  I put olive oil and minced garlic in a bowl and then in the other bowl I measured out the grated parmesan, and I thought I had basil but didn't so I just sprinkled out a bunch of Italian seasoning, then a little garlic salt and a little pepper.  I thought I had bread crumbs but didn't so I took the left over bag of butter and garlic croutons and smashed them up really well and poured that in there.  I was a little concerned but everything turned out so well and everyone loved it!  It didn't taste like too much garlic either.  It worked.

text:
Absolutely delicious! Although many reviews said how moist and juicy chicken was, I gotta say, I still had my doubts. But it's true, it came out very soft inside, and just a little crunchy on the outside. Next time, I will try panko breadcrumbs for more crunch. The only addition I made to the recipe - when the chicken was ready, I sprinkled it with shredded mozzarella cheese and put it back in the oven for a few more minutes. I baked the chicken at 365 for 30 min, and it was perfect! I can't wait to make it again!!!

I've prepared this twice, using it as a kind of jumping off place for my own little touches. The firs time I used egg and a couple of tablespoons fresh cream to coat before the crumb/parmesean mixture, but kept the rest the same. Just today I prepared it again, this time using olive oil, freshly grated parmesean, panko crumbs and added ground italian seasonings to the mix rather than the basil. I also threw in a little extra rosemary. Both times, tho slightly different, it was great. So easy and everyone thinks it took me all day.

I prepared this pretty much as written, though I did add some salt and pepper to the chicken and then let it hang out in the garlic olive oil for a bit to which I added 1t of melted butter. It really is very good and as advertised, a quick, easy recipe that tastes great. The chicken stayed moist at the 350 temp, always a problem with boneless skinless chicken breasts and the bread crumbs browned nicely and did not burn. There are many ways to tweak it, but my point is it's a sound recipe.

text:
I had on hand organic chicken breasts that were thinned sliced and instead of bread crumbs, I used herb stuffing mix from Pep. farm(I crushed it more). I used more olive oil and garlic than the recipe called for and I also used equal parts grated parm and crushed stuffing (1 cup each). The 30 minutes in the oven at 350 was perfect. Nothing was soggy maybe because I used a thinned sliced chicken breast and the stuffing mix instead of breadcrumbs. I served it with just a spinach salad on the side (with almonds, balsamic dressing, dried cherries, little blue cheese). Easy healthy dinner!

text:
Super, super easy. Love that it doesn't require a lot of prep or a lot of cleaning. I hate when people review a recipe according to their own tweaks but the only thing I did differently was I used panko instead of breadcrumbs b/c that's what I had on hand but I don't think this would alter it much. 

My main criticism is that the bottom of the chicken doesn't get crispy (which I suspected but I figured I'd try it as is before changing it). Next time, I'll put it on a rack of something so both sides get crisped. I'll also add some salt and pepper to the chicken b/c I found the end result did need a touch more seasoning. 

(Oh, and my 2 year old said it was "yum" so that makes it all worth it)

this is a keeper i will definitely make it again :)

text:

Everyone else was too nice to complain.  I will not be making this again.

text:
Great dish!  I was very impressed!  We were looking for chicken to eat with chicken Parmesan and this sounded easy and good.  It did not disappoint!  The only substitution I made was because I had run out of bread crumbs and used crushed ritz crackers instead.  Also I used whole chicken breasts and they were pretty big so I added 10 minuted to the cook time.  I checked the internal temp at 30 minutes and they werent quite there but were perfect after 10 additional minutes.  Will be making this again, very easy and my family loved it!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good and very easy.  I did as others suggested and put the olive oil, minced garlic, salt & pepper in a large Zip-loc with the chicken (I used 6 'tenders'), coated all the chicken, then dredged in the Italian breadcrumb/Parmesan cheese mixture.  This worked great and was a snap to clean up.  I did have quite a bit of the breadcrumb/cheese mixture left over, so these quantities could be cut down some.  Otherwise, great recipe with great results.  Served with spaghetti for a traditional Chicken Parmesan.

Delish! didn't give it a "5" because I usually reserve the top rating just in case somthing better turns up.  But this was really good. I used organic, air-chilled chicken breasts that I cut thin enough to cook evenly and made a few changes, based on what I had - romano, panko, and dried Italian herbs - and cooked it in the toaster oven becuase it's soooooo hot here in Central Texas. Served it with a spinach, feta, red onion, mandarin orange, walnut salad dressed with creamy balsamic.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great!  A super-easy weeknight dinner recipe.  I cut the breasts into half width to decrease cooking time.  There's more breading/chicken that way too, which is nice.  I substituted olive oil for the butter, added garlic powder and Italian Seasoning to the breadcrumbs and just a little grated parmesan cheese.  I baked them on a cooling rack, over a pan to catch the crumbs, but did not turn half way through.  The bottoms were not as crisp as the top, so I might do that next time, waiting to add the extra crumb/oil mixture until the cutlets are flipped.  Thanks!

I made this a few times with italian seasoned bread crumbs and the powdery grated parmesan in the green can.  It was very good and easy that way.  But then last night I made this using crushed corn flakes to which I added my own italian seasonings and the grated parmesan that comes in the tubs.  It was fantastic!  So much crispier, and didn't get mushy on the bottom the way the bread crumbs did.

text:
I made this tonight and it was delicious! I followed the recipe exactly except for one thing...I didn't have any basil leaves. Instead, I used a dash of Italian seasoning, and it still tasted wonderful. When it was almost done cooking, I topped it with tomato and sweet basil spaghetti sauce, mozzarella cheese, and sprinkled some parmesan on top and let it bake until the cheese melted. It came out wonderfully. The chicken was juicy, and had a great flavor. Will be a regular on my rotation.

text:
Tasty, easy, good but not great.  I used panko instead of bread crumbs.  I sprayed the panko coating with canola oil and set the oven to broil in the last few minutes to give it the extra crispy crust that we love.  Four large breasts used all the oil and breading.  I also believe that the panko adheres better if you coat the breasts with a light flour then dip into egg.

text:
omigosh, this was so good. i thought this was the first time i followed this recipe, but apparently i had already reviewed it! this time around tasted so much better. i used 3 cloves of garlic, panko bread crumbs, added rosemary to it since that's all i had, and used thigh pieces cut in half. i baked at 350 for 35 minutes. what a great alternative to milk and egg batter. we love garlic, i may add more next time. i will also try topping with fresh parmesan and broiling for the last 5 minutes for extra crunchiness. i also want to try making popcorn chicken. thanks for the recipe, my 4 year old ate A TON!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/72319.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good recipe! Very easy to make! I considered everyone's opinions and substitutions and here's what I did (and I only had approx. 3 T extra of the mixture left - which I sprinkled onto the chicken):

1/2 c of GOOD grated parmesan
1/2 c seasoned italian bread crumbs
1/2 t onion powder
1/2 t garlic powder
1/2 t italian seasoning
1/2 t ground black pepper
2 cloves minced garlic

I made sure 1.) mash the garlic into the oil - to release more of it's flavor into the oil and 2.) to rub the oil and garlic into the chicken breasts before I sprinkled the mixture onto them. It was delicious, moist and great with pasta and marinara sauce. Next time I make this chicken I'll partner it with alfredo! Delish!

Very good.  I made it with chicken tenders tonight and it was delicious.  I increased the garlic and olive oil as I had more pieces to dip and wanted more garlic flavor.  I also warmed the garlic/olive oil mixture in the microwave for about a minute to get the olive oil infused with the garlic first and let it cool before continuing.  Thanks for the recipe.

Display Name:
jelindenhall

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought that this had great flavor and was pleased - but I did make several changes.  First, I doubled the garlic and added 1 tablespooned melted butter to the olive oil. Then, after dipping in the bread crumb mix (which I added 1 tsp. oregano, and a pinch of salt) I browned the chicken about 10 minutes per side before baking in the oven.  After baking for 20 minutes, I added half a jar of marinara sauce and cooked for another 15 minutes.  Then, I topped each piece of chicken with some mozarella cheese and broiled for 5 minutes.  It turned out perfect and will definately make again!

text:
I tried this recipe out because it looked really easy- and it was! I actually made it with mozarella cheese instead of parmesan, because it was all I had, and it turned out just fine. Apparantly I made it with much thicker chicken breasts than the recipe called for, because it actually took a whole hour instead of 30 minutes. I was surprised how juicy it came out. It was a little bland on the inside however, so I'm going to try it again, but with marinated chicken instead.

Display Name:
Neesietoo

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My whole family gave this recipe the thumbs up!  I had more chicken breasts than could fit into a 9x13 pan, so I just made sure that I had enough oil (and pre-chopped garlic in the jar) to coat each piece.  Then I crushed 3/4 of a sleeve of Club crackers and mixed with a generous amount of Parmesan cheese and the spices.  Dry ingredients were put into a baggie and chicken pieces were coated easily by shaking.  Baked under foil for almost a half hour, then remove foil for the last few minutes to 'crispy' it up.  Looks wonderful, tastes delicious and is good enough to serve to company.
Review:
Rating:
4

text:
Clearly, this one is simple as 3-2-1...I sliced each semi-frozen chicken breast into 4 tenders, used only a shake or two of bread crumbs and lots of Johnny's Great Caesar Garlic Spread and Seasoning (mmmmmmmmmm), grated parm, the basil and some other spices and baked for a total of 26 minutes. Served it over tossed blue cheese salad with big fat croutons and a bottle of cheap red wine. Not bad!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
When I made this recipe, I used bone-in thighs.  The flavor was great, but I thought overall it was too heavy and greasy.  The olive oil really stands out (and I used 4 cloves of garlic!) so next time I might try a lighter, but still healthy oil, like grapeseed.  I will also make it again, but with breasts next time.  The drier cut of meat might marry a lot better with the oil.  I gave the recipe four stars for the great flavor of the breading/oil combination and the ease of preparation.
